vulnerabilities.description: Parsing or execution of specially crafted regular expressions in GNU libc (glibc) can exhaust the stack leading to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS), or reduced performance in resource availability. Applications that use the glibc library to process user-supplied regular expression are vulnerable.

GlibC is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the improper management of system memory resources. A local attacker could execute arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system by manipulating environmental variables. It should be noted that this vulnerability is only exploitable for instance of GlibC that are not patched against CVE-2017-1000366.

The GNU C Library (glibc) is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) issue due to the presence of an infinite loop flaw in the `iconv` program. An attacker could invoke the `iconv` program with the `-c` option and supply a crafted input in order to trigger the infinite loop and cause a `iconv` to hang.

glibc is vulnerable to stack overflow protection bypass due to improper handling of stack canary data structures. This could allow an attacker to leverage existing stack-based buffer overflow vulnerabilities.

glibc is vulnerable to arbitrary code execution due to improper memory management when handling ELF files. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a victim with a maliciously crafted ELF file.

glibc is vulnerable to memory protection bypass due to improper memory management during thread creation. This could be leveraged by an attacker to deduce the location of heap memory in order to bypass address space layout randomization (ASLR) protections and successfully exploit memory corruption vulnerabilities.

glibc is vulnerable to memory protection bypass due to improper memory management with thread caches. This could be leveraged by an attacker to deduce the location of stack/heap memory in order to bypass address space layout randomization (ASLR) protections and successfully exploit memory corruption vulnerabilities.
GNU C Library (glibc) is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) condition due to an assertion failure that will result in an application crash.

The GNU C Library (glibc) is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) condition due to the presence of a use-after-free issue in the `mq_notify()` function. `mq_notify()` can attempt to use objects that have been separately allocated leading to instability or a crash.

libiberty (as shipped with GNU binutils and GCC) is vulnerable to a stack-overflow flaw due to infinite recursion in the rust demangler functionality. An attacker who can supply a victim with a specially crafted file could cause a segmentation fault or memory corruption. The most likely outcome will be an application crash. However, when certain stack-overflow protection features are disabled or not available, other impacts to the applications data may occur.
Qt for Windows contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability within the GDI font engine. An attacker could exploit this by loading maliciously crafted or corrupted font data to the application.

GNU glibc contains a vulnerability that can lead to a use-after-free condition. An attacker could exploit this flaw to cause memory corruption, which may result in serious impacts to system confidentiality, integrity and availability. **NOTE:** This issue is only exploitable when a NSS module implements the `_nss_*_gethostbyname2_r` and `_nss_*_getcanonname_r` hooks without implementing the `_nss_*_gethostbyname3_r` hook. There are no known modules that are implemented in this way. Also, the resolved name should return a large number of IPv6 and IPv4 addresses and the call to `getaddrinfo` function should have the `AF_INET6` address family with `AI_CANONNAME`, `AI_ALL` and `AI_V4MAPPED` as set flags. **NOTE:** The fix for this issue introduced a memory leakage vulnerability that has been tracked using **CVE-2023-5156**(**BDSA-2023-2549**). The fix for **CVE-2023-5156** mitigates the problem entirely.

Glibc contains a vulnerability that can lead to a memory leak. An attacker can exploit this flaw and starve the application of available memory. This could result in a denial-of-service (DoS). **Note**: This issue has been introduced in the fix that was implemented for **CVE-2023-4806**(**BDSA-2023-2459**). The fix for **CVE-2023-5156** mitigates the problem entirely.

Oracle OpenJDK and GraalVM for JDK contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An unauthenticated attacker could exploit this by passing a crafted `.509` certificate to cause a frequently repeatable crash. **Note:** The vendor states that "This vulnerability applies to Java deployments, typically in clients running sandboxed Java Web Start applications or sandboxed Java applets, that load and run untrusted code (e.g., code that comes from the internet) and rely on the Java sandbox for security. This vulnerability does not apply to Java deployments, typically in servers, that load and run only trusted code (e.g., code installed by an administrator)."

Oracle OpenJDK contains a data modification vulnerability. An unauthenticated attacker could exploit this to perform an unauthorized update, insert or delete action on some data within the application and bypass Java sandbox restrictions. **Note:** The vendor states that "This vulnerability can only be exploited by supplying data to APIs in the specified Component without using Untrusted Java Web Start applications or Untrusted Java applets, such as through a web service."

Oracle OpenJDK and GraalVM for JDK contains a data modification vulnerability. An unauthenticated attacker, with great effort, could exploit this to perform an unauthorized update, insert or delete action on some data within Oracle OpenJDK and GraalVM for JDK. **Note:** The vendor states that "This vulnerability can be exploited by using APIs in the specified Component, e.g., through a web service which supplies data to the APIs. This vulnerability also applies to Java deployments, typically in clients running sandboxed Java Web Start applications or sandboxed Java applets, that load and run untrusted code (e.g., code that comes from the internet) and rely on the Java sandbox for security."

Logback contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker could exploit this issue by connecting to a receiver and sending maliciously crafted data, which could in turn allow them to slow the logging of events or crash the application. Successful exploitation of this vulnerability requires that logback-receiver component is enabled and also reachable by the attacker.

Bouncy Castle contains an observable timing discrepancy flaw. A remote attacker could leverage this in Bleichenbacher-like attacks to obtain sensitive information through exceptions when processing RSA key exchange handshakes. **Note:** This vulnerability is a timing variant of Bleichenbacher, named "Marvin Attack".

OpenJDK is vulnerable to a memory corruption issue due to the presence of an out-of-bounds array access flaw that can occur in the `hotspot/compiler` functionality as a result of insufficient range checks, specifically within the C1 compiler. A malicious Java application or applet could abuse this flaw in order to corrupt JVM memory and cause a crash, or potentially bypass Java sandbox restrictions and execute arbitrary code.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to a bytecode execution issue due to a verification flaw present in the `hotspot/runtime` functionality. A malicious Java application or applet could abuse this verification flaw in order to execute unverified bytecode that could ultimately result in the bypassing of Java sandbox restrictions.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to a memory corruption issue due to the presence of a loop optimization flaw in the `hotspot/compiler` functionality, specifically within the C2 compiler. A malicious Java application or applet could abuse this flaw in order to corrupt JVM memory and cause a crash, or potentially bypass Java sandbox restrictions and execute arbitrary code.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to a Java code execution bypass issue due to how the `--no-java` option is not sufficiently checked in the `core-libs/javax.script` functionality, specifically within the Nashorn component. Untrusted JavaScript executed within Nashorn could abuse this flaw in order to bypass intended restrictions and execute arbitrary Java code.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to an information disclosure issue due to how private keys used for digital signatures can be logged by the `security-libs/javax.xml.crypto` functionality, specifically the `DOMRSAPSSSignatureMethod` and `DOMSignatureMethod` classes. This issue could result in the exposure of sensitive signature material to actors with access to the debug logs.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to an information disclosure issue due to how the TLS implementation in the `security-libs/java.security` functionality is susceptible to an RSA padding issue and timing side-channel attack. Attackers could potentially abuse this issue in order to access data hat was intended to be protected by encryption measures.

A heap-based buffer overflow vulnerability has been discovered in GNU glibc. The vulnerability occurs due to an off-by-one error in when `__snprintf/__vsnprintf_internal` functions are used for memory allocation. The resulting memory corruption could lead to serious confidentiality, integrity, and availability impacts.

GNU glibc contains an integer overflow vulnerability in `__vsyslog_internal` function. There is a missing check when performing an addition to determine a buffer size. The resulting memory corruption could lead to serious confidentiality, integrity, and availability impacts.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to memory corruption due to an integer overflow issue in the C1 compiler of the Hotspot component, which can lead to out-of-bounds array accesses. This could allow an attacker to obtain unauthorized update, insert or delete access to OpenJDK-accessible data.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to memory corruption due to an integer overflow issue in the C2 compiler of the Hotspot component, which can lead to out-of-bounds array accesses. This could allow an attacker to obtain unauthorized update, insert or delete access to OpenJDK-accessible data.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper memory size validation within the Pack200 archive format implementation. This could allow an attacker to cause resource exhaustion via excessive memory allocation.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper exception handling in the Hotspot component. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying an application with a maliciously crafted long message.

GNU glibc contains an out-of-bounds write vulnerability. An attacker could leverage this, with great effort, to cause a denial-of-service (DoS) via a system crash, information disclosure, modification of neighboring memory or potentially execute remote code. **Note:** The reporter has mentioned [here](https://www.offensivecon.org/speakers/2024/charles-fol.html) that this vulnerability could be used to compromise an entire PHP environment and several PHP applications.

Bouncy Castle is vulnerable to a resource starvation flaw in its handling of certain F2m parameters when importing an EC certificate. A remote attacker may be able to supply such a certificate could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

Bouncy Castle contains a denial-of-service (DoS) flaw as a result of an infinite loop. An attacker could craft a specific signature and public key to trigger an infinite loop, causing the system to become unresponsive or crash due to excessive resource consumption.

Glibc contains a stack-based buffer overflow in its nscd functionality. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause memory corruption, potentially resulting in confidentiality, integrity and availability impacts.

Glibc is vulnerable to null pointer crashes due to a failure in the `addgetnetgrentX` call that may not produce a result. This could allow an attacker to cause a denial of service by triggering a crash.

Glibc is vulnerable to memory corruption due to improper buffer management in the netgroup cache. This could allow an attacker to cause a crash, or potentially leverage corruption to achieve more serious confidentiality and integrity impacts.
Glibc can terminate the process when certain memory allocations fail. A local attacker could leverage this to cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

An issue was discovered in Bouncy Castle Java Cryptography APIs when endpoint identification is enabled in the Java Secure Socket Extension Provider (BCJSSE) and a SSL socket is created without an explicit hostname such as with `HttpsURLConnection`. An attacker could exploit this by performing hostname verification against a DNS-resolved IP address in order to potentially perform DNS poisoning attacks.

Applications using Qt that rely on `QStringDecoder` are vulnerable to an untrusted pointer dereference. A remote attacker targeting such applications may be able to feed the application a crafted input that specifies a specific codec, that when processed could lead to memory corruption via stack modification.

qtnetworkauth uses a weak source (the current system time) for the seed to the pseudo random number generator in the `QAbstractOAuth` network authorization component. This may lead to a weakening of certain cryptographic authorization routines and allow an attacker to leverage a race condition to cause unpredictable behavior, data corruption or system crashes.
OpenJDK's Hotpsot component is vulnerable to unauthorized data modification. A remote attacker could leverage this to update, insert or delete some accessible data.
OpenJDK is vulnerable to unauthorized creation, deletion or modification of critical data via out-of-bounds access to arrays in the Hotspot VM component.
OpenJDK contains various integer wraparound flaws in its Hotspot component. A remote attacker could leverage this to modify critical data.
OpenJDK's Hotspot component improperly handles symbol storage. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause a denial of service.
OpenJDK's Concurrency component fails to properly handle pack 200 loading. A remote attacker could leverage this to cause a denial-of-service (DoS).
OpenJDK's 2D component fails to properly handle images. A remote attacker could leverage this to access unintended data.
curl is vulnerable to an OCSP stapling bypass when using GnuTLS due to improper certificate validation. This could allow an attacker to bypass the certificate status verification process.

Apache Commons IO is vulnerable to excessive resource consumption in its 'XmlStreamReader' component. A remote attacker able to supply the application with specially crafted XML content could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

An issue was discovered in Qtsvg before 6.2.11 and 6.3.x through 6.6.x before 6.6.1. When a QML image refers to an image whose content is not known yet, there is an assumption that it is an SVG document, leading to a denial of service (application crash) if it is not actually an SVG document. **Note: CVE details have been utilized in generating this advisory. The details of the vulnerability have not been independently verified by Black Duck CyRC.**

OpenJDK is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) issue due to a lack of sufficient limits on HTTP header sizes in the `core-libs/java.net` component. An attacker could potentially submit crafted HTTP packets that contain large HTTP headers to Java applications or applets that use the HTTP client libraries in order to cause excessive resource consumption.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to potential data integrity issues due to the existence of vectorization optimization flaws in the `hotspot/compiler` component. An attacker could submit a crafted input to a deployment that uses the affected APIs in order to trigger integer overflows in address computations that cause vectorization optimizations to produce incorrect results. This could cause data corruption and lead to incorrect behavior.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) issue due to a lack of sufficient limits on large indicies in the `MessageFormat` functionality of the `core-libs/java.io:serialization` component. An attacker could submit a crafted input to a Java application that makes use of the `MessageFormat` functionality that, during the deserialization process, could trigger out-of-memory conditions as a result of unbounded allocation.

OpenJDK is vulnerable to information disclosure and data integrity issues due to the presence of integer conversion errors in the `hotspot/compiler` component. An attacker could submit a crafted input to an application that utilizes the HotSpot JVM in order to trigger an integer overflow during the loop optimization phase of processing. This issue could lead to incorrect optimizations and cause unintended behavior.

curl is vulnerable to a sensitive information disclosure issue due to how it is possible for passwords to be leaked to unintended hosts when using a `.netrc` file for credentials, and HTTP redirects are followed. In these cases, a password used for the first host can be leaked to the followed-to host. This issue requires the `.netrc` file to contain an entry that matches the redirect target hostname, but this entry must also omit the password or the login and password.

Logback is vulnerable to server-side request forgery (SSRF). A local attacker could embed external links in DOCTYPE declarations in XML configuration files. This would cause the server to submit web requests to the attacker's specified location.

logback is vulnerable to arbitrary code execution due to unsafe operations within the `JaninoEventEvaluator` extension. A local privileged attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a system with a malicious configuration file, either by overwriting an existing configuration or injecting an environment variable pointing to a crafted configuration.

GNU Glibc contains a memory corruption vulnerability that overflows the heap buffer by one or several bytes. The corruption occurs when the `assert()` function fails under specific conditions. Heap buffer overflows are known to result in severe damage to the program's confidentiality, integrity, and availability, however the credited researchers have only demonstrated denial-of-service (DoS) via segmentation fault, and the vendor believes the vulnerability is relatively minor. It may only be exploited via custom setuid programs, and none of the known/default UNIX programs are affected.

curl is vulnerable to a sensitive information disclosure issue due to how it is possible for passwords to be leaked to unintended hosts when using a `.netrc` file for credentials, and HTTP redirects are followed. In these cases, a password used for the first host can be leaked to the followed-to host. This issue can occur if the `.netrc` file has a `default` entry that omits both login and password information.

curl, when using zlib **1.2.0.3** or older, is vulnerable to a memory corruption issue due to how a buffer overflow can occur as a result of an integer overflow during automatic gzip decompression of content-encoded HTTP responses with the `CURLOPT_ACCEPT_ENCODING` option enabled. A malicious HTTP server could use this flaw to craft an arbitrary heap chunk in the memory of the victim and issue a `free()` on the forged chunk. **Note**: This issue can only be triggered when using an outdated runtime zlib version **1.2.0.3** or older. **1.2.0.4** was released in August 2003.
OpenJDK is vulnerable to side-channel analysis in its handling of RSA PKCS#1 v1.5 padding errors. A remote attacker could leverage this to affect the confidentiality and integrity of messages.
OpenJDK's hotspot compiler component improperly handles certain transformations when numeric overflows can occur. A remote attacker could leverage this for low confidentiality and integrity impacts.
OpenJDK's 2D image handling component is vulnerable to integer underflows and overflows leading to memory corruption.

In the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) before 2.28, parse_reg_exp in posix/regcomp.c misparses alternatives, which allows attackers to cause a denial of service (assertion failure and application exit) or trigger an incorrect result by attempting a regular-expression match.

The pop_fail_stack function in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) allows context-dependent attackers to cause a denial of service (assertion failure and application crash) via vectors related to extended regular expression processing.

In the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.28, the getaddrinfo function would successfully parse a string that contained an IPv4 address followed by whitespace and arbitrary characters, which could lead applications to incorrectly assume that it had parsed a valid string, without the possibility of embedded HTTP headers or other potentially dangerous substrings.

The GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) before 2.27 contains an off-by-one error leading to a heap-based buffer overflow in the glob function in glob.c, related to the processing of home directories using the ~ operator followed by a long string.

The glob function in glob.c in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) before 2.27, when invoked with GLOB_TILDE, could skip freeing allocated memory when processing the ~ operator with a long user name, potentially leading to a denial of service (memory leak).
The glob function in glob.c in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) before 2.27 contains a buffer overflow during unescaping of user names with the ~ operator.

elf/dl-load.c in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) 2.19 through 2.26 mishandles RPATH and RUNPATH containing $ORIGIN for a privileged (setuid or AT_SECURE) program, which allows local users to gain privileges via a Trojan horse library in the current working directory, related to the fillin_rpath and decompose_rpath functions. This is associated with misinterpretion of an empty RPATH/RUNPATH token as the "./" directory. NOTE: this configuration of RPATH/RUNPATH for a privileged program is apparently very uncommon; most likely, no such program is shipped with any common Linux distribution.

The malloc function in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) 2.26 could return a memory block that is too small if an attempt is made to allocate an object whose size is close to SIZE_MAX, potentially leading to a subsequent heap overflow. This occurs because the per-thread cache (aka tcache) feature enables a code path that lacks an integer overflow check.

An SSE2-optimized memmove implementation for i386 in sysdeps/i386/i686/multiarch/memcpy-sse2-unaligned.S in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) 2.21 through 2.27 does not correctly perform the overlapping memory check if the source memory range spans the middle of the address space, resulting in corrupt data being produced by the copy operation. This may disclose information to context-dependent attackers, or result in a denial of service, or, possibly, code execution.

In glibc 2.26 and earlier there is confusion in the usage of getcwd() by realpath() which can be used to write before the destination buffer leading to a buffer underflow and potential code execution.

stdlib/canonicalize.c in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) 2.27 and earlier, when processing very long pathname arguments to the realpath function, could encounter an integer overflow on 32-bit architectures, leading to a stack-based buffer overflow and, potentially, arbitrary code execution.

An AVX-512-optimized implementation of the mempcpy function in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) 2.27 and earlier may write data beyond the target buffer, leading to a buffer overflow in __mempcpy_avx512_no_vzeroupper.

In the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.28, attempting to resolve a crafted hostname via getaddrinfo() leads to the allocation of a socket descriptor that is not closed. This is related to the if_nametoindex() function.
In the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.29, check_dst_limits_calc_pos_1 in posix/regexec.c has Uncontrolled Recursion, as demonstrated by '(\227|)(\\1\\1|t1|\\\2537)+' in grep.

An integer overflow in the implementation of the posix_memalign in memalign functions in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) 2.26 and earlier could cause these functions to return a pointer to a heap area that is too small, potentially leading to heap corruption.

The malloc implementation in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6), from version 2.24 to 2.26 on powerpc, and only in version 2.26 on i386, did not properly handle malloc calls with arguments close to SIZE_MAX and could return a pointer to a heap region that is smaller than requested, eventually leading to heap corruption.

On the x86-64 architecture, the GNU C Library (aka glibc) before 2.31 fails to ignore the LD_PREFER_MAP_32BIT_EXEC environment variable during program execution after a security transition, allowing local attackers to restrict the possible mapping addresses for loaded libraries and thus bypass ASLR for a setuid program.
The iconv feature in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.32, when processing invalid multi-byte input sequences in the EUC-KR encoding, may have a buffer over-read.

The string component in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.28, when running on the x32 architecture, incorrectly attempts to use a 64-bit register for size_t in assembly codes, which can lead to a segmentation fault or possibly unspecified other impact, as demonstrated by a crash in __memmove_avx_unaligned_erms in sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/memmove-vec-unaligned-erms.S during a memcpy.

In the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.29, the memcmp function for the x32 architecture can incorrectly return zero (indicating that the inputs are equal) because the RDX most significant bit is mishandled.
In the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.29, proceed_next_node in posix/regexec.c has a heap-based buffer over-read via an attempted case-insensitive regular-expression match.

In the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) through 2.29, check_dst_limits_calc_pos_1 in posix/regexec.c has Uncontrolled Recursion, as demonstrated by '(|)(\\1\\1)*' in grep, a different issue than CVE-2018-20796. NOTE: the software maintainer disputes that this is a vulnerability because the behavior occurs only with a crafted pattern

The GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) before 2.32 could overflow an on-stack buffer during range reduction if an input to an 80-bit long double function contains a non-canonical bit pattern, a seen when passing a 0x5d414141414141410000 value to sinl on x86 targets. This is related to sysdeps/ieee754/ldbl-96/e_rem_pio2l.c.

An out-of-bounds write vulnerability was found in glibc before 2.31 when handling signal trampolines on PowerPC. Specifically, the backtrace function did not properly check the array bounds when storing the frame address, resulting in a denial of service or potential code execution. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.

A use-after-free vulnerability introduced in glibc upstream version 2.14 was found in the way the tilde expansion was carried out. Directory paths containing an initial tilde followed by a valid username were affected by this issue. A local attacker could exploit this flaw by creating a specially crafted path that, when processed by the glob function, would potentially lead to arbitrary code execution. This was fixed in version 2.32.

The iconv function in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) 2.32 and earlier, when processing invalid multi-byte input sequences in IBM1364, IBM1371, IBM1388, IBM1390, and IBM1399 encodings, fails to advance the input state, which could lead to an infinite loop in applications, resulting in a denial of service, a different vulnerability from CVE-2016-10228.

An exploitable signed comparison vulnerability exists in the ARMv7 memcpy() implementation of GNU glibc 2.30.9000. Calling memcpy() (on ARMv7 targets that utilize the GNU glibc implementation) with a negative value for the 'num' parameter results in a signed comparison vulnerability. If an attacker underflows the 'num' parameter to memcpy(), this vulnerability could lead to undefined behavior such as writing to out-of-bounds memory and potentially remote code execution. Furthermore, this memcpy() implementation allows for program execution to continue in scenarios where a segmentation fault or crash should have occurred. The dangers occur in that subsequent execution and iterations of this code will be executed with this corrupted data.

The iconv function in the GNU C Library (aka glibc or libc6) 2.32 and earlier, when processing invalid input sequences in the ISO-2022-JP-3 encoding, fails an assertion in the code path and aborts the program, potentially resulting in a denial of service.

The wordexp function in the GNU C Library (aka glibc) through 2.33 may crash or read arbitrary memory in parse_param (in posix/wordexp.c) when called with an untrusted, crafted pattern, potentially resulting in a denial of service or disclosure of information. This occurs because atoi was used but strtoul should have been used to ensure correct calculations.

In librt in the GNU C Library (aka glibc) through 2.34, sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/mq_notify.c mishandles certain NOTIFY_REMOVED data, leading to a NULL pointer dereference. NOTE: this vulnerability was introduced as a side effect of the CVE-2021-33574 fix.

A flaw was found in glibc. An off-by-one buffer overflow and underflow in getcwd() may lead to memory corruption when the size of the buffer is exactly 1. A local attacker who can control the input buffer and size passed to getcwd() in a setuid program could use this flaw to potentially execute arbitrary code and escalate their privileges on the system.

The deprecated compatibility function svcunix_create in the sunrpc module of the GNU C Library (aka glibc) through 2.34 copies its path argument on the stack without validating its length, which may result in a buffer overflow, potentially resulting in a denial of service or (if an application is not built with a stack protector enabled) arbitrary code execution.

The deprecated compatibility function clnt_create in the sunrpc module of the GNU C Library (aka glibc) through 2.34 copies its hostname argument on the stack without validating its length, which may result in a buffer overflow, potentially resulting in a denial of service or (if an application is not built with a stack protector enabled) arbitrary code execution.

zip4j up to v2.10.0 can throw various uncaught exceptions while parsing a specially crafted ZIP file, which could result in an application crash. This could be used to mount a denial of service attack against services that use zip4j library.

A vulnerability was found in GNU C Library 2.38. It has been declared as critical. This vulnerability affects the function __monstartup of the file gmon.c of the component Call Graph Monitor. The manipulation leads to buffer overflow. It is recommended to apply a patch to fix this issue. VDB-220246 is the identifier assigned to this vulnerability. NOTE: The real existence of this vulnerability is still doubted at the moment. The inputs that induce this vulnerability are basically addresses of the running application that is built with gmon enabled. It's basically trusted input or input that needs an actual security flaw to be compromised or controlled.
Zip4j through 2.11.2, as used in Threema and other products, does not always check the MAC when decrypting a ZIP archive.

Bouncy Castle For Java before 1.74 is affected by an LDAP injection vulnerability. The vulnerability only affects applications that use an LDAP CertStore from Bouncy Castle to validate X.509 certificates. During the certificate validation process, Bouncy Castle inserts the certificate's Subject Name into an LDAP search filter without any escaping, which leads to an LDAP injection vulnerability.

Bouncy Castle for Java before 1.73 contains a potential Denial of Service (DoS) issue within the Bouncy Castle org.bouncycastle.openssl.PEMParser class. This class parses OpenSSL PEM encoded streams containing X.509 certificates, PKCS8 encoded keys, and PKCS7 objects. Parsing a file that has crafted ASN.1 data through the PEMParser causes an OutOfMemoryError, which can enable a denial of service attack. (For users of the FIPS Java API: BC-FJA 1.0.2.3 and earlier are affected; BC-FJA 1.0.2.4 is fixed.)

jackson-databind through 2.15.2 allows attackers to cause a denial of service or other unspecified impact via a crafted object that uses cyclic dependencies. NOTE: the vendor's perspective is that this is not a valid vulnerability report, because the steps of constructing a cyclic data structure and trying to serialize it cannot be achieved by an external attacker.

**DISPUTED**A failure in the -fstack-protector feature in GCC-based toolchains that target AArch64 allows an attacker to exploit an existing buffer overflow in dynamically-sized local variables in your application without this being detected. This stack-protector failure only applies to C99-style dynamically-sized local variables or those created using alloca(). The stack-protector operates as intended for statically-sized local variables. The default behavior when the stack-protector detects an overflow is to terminate your application, resulting in controlled loss of availability. An attacker who can exploit a buffer overflow without triggering the stack-protector might be able to change program flow control to cause an uncontrolled loss of availability or to go further and affect confidentiality or integrity. NOTE: The GCC project argues that this is a missed hardening bug and not a vulnerability by itself.

A flaw was found in glibc. When the getaddrinfo function is called with the AF_UNSPEC address family and the system is configured with no-aaaa mode via /etc/resolv.conf, a DNS response via TCP larger than 2048 bytes can potentially disclose stack contents through the function returned address data, and may cause a crash.

A flaw was found in glibc. In an uncommon situation, the gaih_inet function may use memory that has been freed, resulting in an application crash. This issue is only exploitable when the getaddrinfo function is called and the hosts database in /etc/nsswitch.conf is configured with SUCCESS=continue or SUCCESS=merge.

An issue was discovered in the HTTP2 implementation in Qt before 5.15.17, 6.x before 6.2.11, 6.3.x through 6.5.x before 6.5.4, and 6.6.x before 6.6.2. network/access/http2/hpacktable.cpp has an incorrect HPack integer overflow check.
A serialization vulnerability in logback receiver component part of logback version 1.4.13,1.3.13 and1.2.12 allows an attacker to mount a Denial-Of-Service attack by sending poisoned data.

runc is a CLI tool for spawning and running containers on Linux according to the OCI specification. In runc 1.1.11 and earlier, due to an internal file descriptor leak, an attacker could cause a newly-spawned container process (from runc exec) to have a working directory in the host filesystem namespace, allowing for a container escape by giving access to the host filesystem ("attack 2"). The same attack could be used by a malicious image to allow a container process to gain access to the host filesystem through runc run ("attack 1"). Variants of attacks 1 and 2 could be also be used to overwrite semi-arbitrary host binaries, allowing for complete container escapes ("attack 3a" and "attack 3b"). runc 1.1.12 includes patches for this issue.

Loop with Unreachable Exit Condition ('Infinite Loop') vulnerability in Apache Commons Compress.This issue affects Apache Commons Compress: from 1.3 through 1.25.0. Users are recommended to upgrade to version 1.26.0 which fixes the issue.

Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling vulnerability in Apache Commons Compress.This issue affects Apache Commons Compress: from 1.21 before 1.26. Users are recommended to upgrade to version 1.26, which fixes the issue.

An issue was discovered in HTTP2 in Qt before 5.15.18, 6.x before 6.2.13, 6.3.x through 6.5.x before 6.5.7, and 6.6.x through 6.7.x before 6.7.3. Code to make security-relevant decisions about an established connection may execute too early, because the encrypted() signal has not yet been emitted and processed..

libcurl's ASN1 parser has this utf8asn1str() function used for parsing an ASN.1 UTF-8 string. Itcan detect an invalid field and return error. Unfortunately, when doing so it also invokes `free()` on a 4 byte localstack buffer. Most modern malloc implementations detect this error and immediately abort. Some however accept the input pointer and add that memory to its list of available chunks. This leads to the overwriting of nearby stack memory. The content of the overwrite is decided by the `free()` implementation; likely to be memory pointers and a set of flags. The most likely outcome of exploting this flaw is a crash, although it cannot be ruled out that more serious results can be had in special circumstances.

libcurl's ASN1 parser code has the `GTime2str()` function, used for parsing an ASN.1 Generalized Time field. If given an syntactically incorrect field, the parser might end up using -1 for the length of the *time fraction*, leading to a `strlen()` getting performed on a pointer to a heap buffer area that is not (purposely) null terminated. This flaw most likely leads to a crash, but can also lead to heap contents getting returned to the application when [CURLINFO_CERTINFO](https://curl.se/libcurl/c/CURLINFO_CERTINFO.html) is used.

When curl is asked to use HSTS, the expiry time for a subdomain might overwrite a parent domain's cache entry, making it end sooner or later than otherwise intended. This affects curl using applications that enable HSTS and use URLs with the insecure `HTTP://` scheme and perform transfers with hosts like `x.example.com` as well as `example.com` where the first host is a subdomain of the second host. (The HSTS cache either needs to have been populated manually or there needs to have been previous HTTPS accesses done as the cache needs to have entries for the domains involved to trigger this problem.) When `x.example.com` responds with `Strict-Transport-Security:` headers, this bug can make the subdomain's expiry timeout *bleed over* and get set for the parent domain `example.com` in curl's HSTS cache. The result of a triggered bug is that HTTP accesses to `example.com` get converted to HTTPS for a different period of time than what was asked for by the origin server. If `example.com` for example stops supporting HTTPS at its expiry time, curl might then fail to access `http://example.com` until the (wrongly set) timeout expires. This bug can also expire the parent's entry *earlier*, thus making curl inadvertently switch back to insecure HTTP earlier than otherwise intended.
encodeText in QDom in Qt before 6.8.0 has a complex algorithm involving XML string copy and inline replacement of parts of a string (with relocation of later data).
